title: 114_hr429
content: The Act may be cited as the "Grand Jury Reform Act of 2015". The Congress acknowledges the close relationship between local prosecutors and law enforcement officers in grand jury investigations, leading to public suspicion of preferential treatment for accused police officers. Police officers have the right to testify before grand juries without thorough cross-examination, as these proceedings are secret by law. The secretive grand jury process historically favors law enforcement officers, leading to public distrust. Recent cases involving the deaths of Michael Brown and Eric Garner ended with no indictments for the officers involved, further eroding confidence in the justice system. Preliminary hearings are often skipped in favor of direct presentments by prosecutors. The secretive grand jury process often leads to public distrust, as seen in cases like Michael Brown and Eric Garner. Prosecutors can bypass preliminary hearings and send cases directly to the grand jury for consideration. "SEC. 3. HEARING BEFORE A JUDGE REQUIRED." In order to receive Federal funding under certain provisions of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968, a State or local government must comply with notification requirements regarding the use of deadly force by law enforcement officers. The chief officer of a law enforcement agency must report any death caused by an officer's use of deadly force to the elected prosecutor and the governor within 24 hours. The elected prosecutor must report any death caused by an officer's use of deadly force to the Governor within 24 hours. The Governor must appoint a special prosecutor within 3 days to determine if criminal charges should be brought against the officer. The Governor must appoint a special prosecutor within 3 days of a death caused by an officer's use of deadly force. The special prosecutor will be selected randomly from elected prosecutors in the State, excluding the prosecutor of the locality where the death occurred. The hearing must be held within 90 days, with the court remaining open to the public. The State Law Enforcement Agency has exclusive authority over the investigation. The Governor appoints a special prosecutor within 3 days of a death caused by an officer's use of deadly force. The State Law Enforcement Agency has exclusive authority over the investigation, with the chief officer assuming control and cooperation from local law enforcement. After a death caused by an officer's use of deadly force, a special prosecutor is appointed by the Governor within 3 days. The judge presiding over a hearing must issue a written determination of probable cause within 5 days, which is then submitted to the elected prosecutor. The special prosecutor provides written recommendations to the elected prosecutor, including whether criminal charges should be brought against the officer. Procedural deadlines are tolled during the investigation. After a death caused by an officer's use of deadly force, a special prosecutor is appointed by the Governor within 3 days. The judge presiding over a hearing must issue a written determination of probable cause within 5 days. The hearing described in subsection (c) is purely advisory and has no binding effect on the elected prosecutor. The elected prosecutor retains prosecutorial discretion after the hearing, including the decision to bring charges against the law enforcement officer.
